they know who it was.
I think I do too.
I really do think the lady knows my money's on the lady in times of knowing.
Yeah, I think so.
Let's listen to him again here.
Kevin.
At least five shots fired.
Depends who you talk to.
Are you surprised that there are no witnesses?
No.
Yeah.
Tim Warren, Lois, and Ernest Bowen Camp and Romaine Henry.
None of them were present at the shooting and no one who was there, including the mayor
of Skidmore would talk to us.
A grand jury was convened and came up with no indictment.
A person or persons unknown killed the man.
Tell me something.
Are you glad he's gone?
I would say we're all resting a lot better now, knowing that the man does not, is not
here.
If they catch somebody and he's tried and he's found guilty.
Would you feel that justice has been done?
No.
Because there's no town.
That's a train.
Fadden.
You take the lawyer and you take the courts.
It wasn't the town that killed McElroy.
It was them.
It's the way I feel.
They're not lucky about it.
Well, yes.
What they did was worse than anything they could say about him.
They went outside that system of justice and they took the law on their own hands, in my
opinion, and they decided they were going to get rid of him.
Do you want to know who did it?
No.
No.
Would you turn it in the person who did it if you had absolute proof they did it?
No.
No, sir, they're not.
Would you, preacher?
No.
I wouldn't.
Doesn't that bother your conscience a bit?
No.
Because there's a verse in the Old Testament that says, who's whoever's shedeth man's
blood by man, so shall his blood be shed.
The murder of Ken Rex McElroy remains unsolved.
In theory, the investigation continues, but as far as we can determine, there is very
little hope of a break in the case.
Trena McElroy, they say, has offered a $10,000 reward, but so far no takers.
Through lawyer McFadden, she's signed a movie deal, of course.
As for Skidmore, no one is talking whether they have anything to say or not.
They now feel secure, but they are still uneasy.
For among them now, there is a murderer.
The American judicial system failed in Skidmore, Missouri.
It failed twice.
Yeah, I think they're sleeping uneasy, right?
Right, right.
Among them is a murderer.
I don't think those people feel that way.
No.
I don't think so either.
No.
And again, they go back to the Ides of March, 44 BC.
There's a reason that all the conspirators got in one blade's worth of stab at minimum.
They were all going to be complicit.
I don't think there's a murderer in Skidmore when that 60 minutes guys are doing the story.
I think there's at least five, maybe 10.
And they did it in such a way that nobody could say exactly who even did it.
Now when Caesar was killed, did all the conspirators stab him or is that just the way Shakespeare
wrote it?
John Brutus.
Yeah.
Well, I mean, I understand that that was written by Shakespeare, but is there like an external
source?
Mm-hmm.
Oh, okay.
Yeah.
Yeah.
The ancient Roman historians.
How many of them were they dipped their knives or their in his blood too, right?
I mean, they came to ultimately show that they did it.
Well, yes, they went right out and announced to the world this is what we did.
Right.
Wow.
And the guy who led it, Marcus Junius Brutus was like the grandson of the guy who deposed
the last tyrant when the Republic was in peril.
And so they followed a playbook from even earlier that they would say it was the same
moral conundrum.
And it put them in a situation where they felt like that was what they had to do.
That was their responsibility.
You know what, what I think is interesting here in the battle in West Virginia, where
the coal miners went up against the businesses, it was veterans that actually led the charge.
It was organ basically, they saw a lady and her children get thrown out in the street
by a company in broad daylight while the guy was at work.
And a couple of veterans from World War I, they were like, Oh, no.
And they organized and they just took them on.
The meeting that was called before McElroy was killed was at the VFW.
Yeah.
The veterans of foreign wars, the town, you know, they're right across the street from
the D and G.
Yeah.
Tavern.
And so I wonder if there's a with is 81, I wonder if there's somebody that was in Vietnam,
the timing would work out.
I wonder if there was somebody that was from that war or from Korea, even that figured
it out.
My grandfather ran a bulldozer off of his property one time with an M1 carbine.
Somebody was taking down trees.
They shouldn't have.
And his first response was, okay, time to get my carbine from back in my Korea days
and go run that bulldozer off the property.
And so I wonder if you had a couple of veterans that that bowed up.
I'm from a small town.
So I know a lot of people from small towns, but I know a lot of veterans from small towns.
When you look at the, you know, the situation a few generations ago, the economic situation,
I know a lot of people who signed up and went to war and not only for their country, but
for, you know, economic reasons, because they could make a living, you know, as a soldier.
And then when you sort of lay that against this kind of town, you know, where there are,
I think it's perfectly reasonable to assume that there's some veterans and skid more.
This is a fascinating historical moral social exercise.
And I think it's okay on the one level for us to look at it as observers and just think
about the nuts and bolts.
And this was super instructive.
It's super well prepared by the way, Daelyn.
Thank you very, very much for all of the work you put into it.
But I also think it's okay after we've done the nuts and bolts work to indulge as we
did just a little bit in thinking about the moral implications and what we do if we were
there.
And I think this one's a little murky.
Yeah, it's definitely a little murky.
And I think that life and history and culture and all of that gets a little murky sometimes.
And to be able to sort of think through it and discuss it and learn from it as best we
can is the best possible response to that murkiness.
Hmm.
One thing's for sure though, the people of the town, there's some trust that still exists
there.
There's a bond.
So trust in each other, even though there's not trust in the system, that's interesting.
There's like a profound sense of trust and solidarity amongst the people within the town,
even when trust in the system and the government and authority, all of that broke down.
They reverted back to what we have as each other.
Great stuff, gentlemen.
Yeah, I liked it.
Guys, this was a blast.
I mean, I was kind of sheepish in terms of picking this topic.
I didn't know if it would be too dark or not.
And another thing was like, there was so much really good journalism about it.
I kind of felt like I was in the shadow of people who did a much better job communicating
the story, but I think it went pretty well.
I think you did a great job, man.
Thanks, Josh.
I think so too.
Thanks, Josh.
